*The Scripture on the Merits and Gravity of the Three Primal Precepts from the Supreme Cavernous Mystery Numinous Treasure*

Thus spake the Heavenly Worthy:

In the Upper Primal Realm, the Celestial Officials of the First Order, where primordial qi first congeals and the Three Luminaries dawn in radiance, the essences of azure, yellow, and white qi coalesce to establish the Three Palaces of the Upper Primal. The first of these is named the Supreme Cavernous Mystery Primordial Yang Seven-Jewel Purple Tenuity Palace. Therein resides the azure primordial yang qi, governing the Perfected of the Upper Realms, the Celestial August Emperor of the Jade Void, the Divine Sovereigns of the Heavens, and the exalted deities of the highest sanctity.

This palace is arrayed in fifty-five myriad, five thousand five hundred fifty-five myriad, five myriad layers, enveloped likewise in fifty-five myriad, five thousand five hundred fifty-five myriad, five myriad layers of azure yang qi. Within it, the divine immortals and their retinues number fifty-five myriad, five thousand five hundred fifty-five myriad, five myriad, as do their multitudes—all formed from the spontaneous coagulation of azure primordial qi into human form. Their raiment is of azure feathered flight-garments.

Within the Purple Tenuity Palace lies the Talisman of Prolonged Life. When this talisman is inscribed and placed in the eight directions, the qi of those regions rushes forth in response, manifesting as human beings. Should the talisman be destroyed and burned in fire, the people dissolve with the smoke, reverting to qi. None but those who have attained the Dao with golden tablets and jade names may wield it. Its script emerges but once every forty thousand kalpas, overseen by the Fire Officials of the Great Yang and enacted by the Upper Repository of the Supreme Cavernous Mystery.

The Purple Tenuity Palace contains three bureaus: left, right, and central. The Left Bureau governs life, examined by the Fire Officials of the Great Yang. The Right Bureau governs death, examined by the Water Officials of the Great Yin. The Central Bureau governs the records of life, death, transgressions, and the trials of the Wind Blade.

Each bureau commands a retinue of ninety million officials, collectively administering the twelve departments of life, death, transgressions, and blessings:

1. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Illuminated Perfection Department
2. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Surveillance and Rectification Department
3. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Brahman Conduct Department
4. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Unfolding Numinosity Department
5. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Spirit-Restraining Department
6. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Luminous Clarity Department
7. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Rectified Spirits Department
8. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Unfolding Clarity Department
9. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Three Capitals Department
10. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Southern Ascendant Department
11. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Primordial Merit Department
12. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Three Numinosities Department

These twelve departments were established by the Supreme Cavernous Mystery Lady of Azure, subordinate to the Purple Tenuity Palace. They govern the Left Bureau’s Great Yang Fire Officials, the Right Bureau’s Great Yin Water Officials, and the Central Bureau’s trials by Wind Blade. Each department comprises one hundred twenty examining officials, one thousand two hundred examining scribes, twelve thousand examining soldiers, and one hundred twenty thousand examining scholars. They oversee the registers of the Upper Perfected who have attained the Dao in past kalpas, those yet to attain it in the present blessings, and the merits and transgressions of all men and women among the common folk.

Major trials occur every three years, intermediate trials every nine years, and minor trials every twenty-four years. Major blessings are bestowed every three years, intermediate blessings every nine years, and minor blessings every twenty-four years. Transgressions and blessings are meted out together, merits and demerits recompensed alike. The ledgers of good and evil are stored within the Seven-Jewel Casket of the Illuminated Perfection Jade Coffer in the Cavernous Mystery Capital.

In the Upper Primal Realm, the left palace of the primordial yellow qi of the Central Yellow is named the Supreme Cavernous Mystery Primordial Yellow Supreme Ultimate Left Palace. Therein resides the primordial yellow qi of the Origin, governing the registers of life for the Upper Perfected who have attained the Dao in past kalpas, those yet to attain it, and all men and women among the common folk.

This palace is arrayed in fifty-five myriad, five thousand five hundred fifty-five myriad, five myriad layers, enveloped likewise in fifty-five myriad, five thousand five hundred fifty-five myriad, five myriad layers of primordial yellow qi. Within it, the divine immortals and their retinues number fifty-five myriad, five thousand five hundred fifty-five myriad, five myriad, as do their multitudes—all formed from the spontaneous coagulation of primordial yellow qi into human form. Their raiment is of yellow feathered flight-garments.

Within the Supreme Ultimate Left Palace lies the Talisman of Summoning Spirits. Its method of use follows the same rites and standards as the Talisman of Prolonged Life in the Purple Tenuity Palace. It is overseen by the Wind Blade Examining Officials and enacted by the Left Repository of the Supreme Cavernous Mystery.

The Supreme Ultimate Left Palace contains three bureaus: left, right, and central. The Left Bureau governs life, examined by the Great Yang Fire Officials. The Right Bureau governs death, examined by the Great Yin Water Officials. The Central Bureau governs the records of life, death, transgressions, and the trials of the Wind Blade.

Each bureau commands a retinue of ninety million officials, collectively administering the twelve departments of life, death, transgressions, and blessings:

1. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Illuminated Brahman Department
2. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Majestic Numinosity Department
3. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Grand Constancy Department
4. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Grand Purity Department
5. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Proclaiming Majesty Department
6. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Illuminated Capital Department
7. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Capital Numinosity Department
8. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Grand Ceremony Department
9. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Illuminated Dharma Department
10. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Examining Rectification Department
11. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Illuminated Majesty Department
12. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Nine Capitals Department

These twelve departments were established by the Supreme Cavernous Mystery Lady of Azure, subordinate to the Primordial Yellow Supreme Ultimate Left Palace. They govern the Left Bureau’s Great Yang Fire Palace, the Right Bureau’s Great Yin Water Palace, and the Central Bureau’s trials by Wind Blade. Each department comprises one hundred twenty examining officials, one thousand two hundred examining scribes, twelve thousand examining soldiers, and one hundred twenty thousand examining scholars. They oversee the life registers of the Upper Perfected who have attained the Dao in past kalpas, those yet to attain it in the present blessings, and all men and women among the common folk, as well as those destined to attain immortality with jade tablets on the right.

The recording of merits and demerits, the erasure or retention of ranks, and the retribution of sins and blessings follow the same time limits as those of the Purple Tenuity Palace. The registers are sealed within the Yang-Generating Case of the Mysterious Capital’s Luminous Perfected Jade Coffer. The Right Palace of the Supreme Cavernous Primordial White Qi of the First-Rank Upper Primordial Heaven, named the Supreme Cavernous Primordial White Supreme Ultimate Right Palace, is governed by the Primordial Cavernous White Qi. It oversees the registers of the Upper Perfected who have attained the Dao in past kalpas, those yet to attain it, the records of common men and women’s transcendence and immortal ascension, as well as the death registers of the condemned. This palace comprises fifty billion, five myriad, fifty-five hundred million, fifty-five myriad, fifty-five layers, and is also enveloped by fifty billion, five myriad, fifty-five hundred million, fifty-five myriad layers of Cavernous White Qi. The divine immortals and officials within likewise number fifty billion, five myriad, fifty-five hundred million, fifty-five myriad, and are also fifty billion, five myriad, fifty-five hundred million, fifty-five myriad in multitude. All are formed from the natural Cavernous White Qi into human form. They wear feathered flying robes of white.

Within the Supreme Ultimate Right Palace resides the Luminous Perfected Talisman, whose usage and regulations follow the same rites of life extension as those of the Purple Tenuity Palace. The Palace of Great Yin Water governs its examinations, and the Supreme Cavernous Right Bureau enforces them. The Supreme Ultimate Right Palace comprises three bureaus: Left, Right, and Central. The Left Bureau governs life and is examined by the Palace of Great Yang Fire. The Right Bureau governs death and is examined by the Palace of Great Yin Water. The Central Bureau governs the trials of life, death, and sin by Wind Blade. Each of the three palaces commands ninety million officials and collectively oversees the twelve departments of life, death, sin, and blessing:

Supreme Cavernous Upper Primordial Rectifying Department.
Supreme Cavernous Upper Primordial Four Luminaries Department.
Supreme Cavernous Upper Primordial Celestial Surveillance Department.
Supreme Cavernous Upper Primordial Execution Department.
Supreme Cavernous Upper Primordial Celestial Covenant Department.
Supreme Cavernous Upper Primordial Dark Capital Department.
Supreme Cavernous Upper Primordial Dignity Department.
Supreme Cavernous Upper Primordial Great Yin Department.
Supreme Cavernous Upper Primordial Lower Primordial Department.
Supreme Cavernous Upper Primordial Surveillance Department.
Supreme Cavernous Upper Primordial Spirit-Watching Department.
Supreme Cavernous Upper Primordial Great Luminosity Department.

These twelve departments were established by the Supreme Cavernous Mystery Lady of Azure and are subordinate to the Primordial Cavernous White Supreme Ultimate Right Palace. They govern the Left Bureau’s Palace of Great Yang Fire, the Right Bureau’s Palace of Great Yin Water, and the Central Bureau’s trials by Wind Blade. Each department comprises one hundred twenty examining officials, one thousand two hundred examining scribes, twelve thousand examining soldiers, and one hundred twenty thousand examining scholars. They oversee the comprehensive registers of the Upper Perfected who have attained the Dao in past kalpas, those yet to attain it in the present blessings, and all common men and women whose names are to be erased from the immortal records due to transcendence or death, recording their dates. They determine the ranks of immortals, the retribution of sins and blessings, following the same time limits as those of the Purple Tenuity Palace. The registers are sealed within the Northern Repository Case of the Nine Dark Jade Coffer of the Everlasting Night Bureau.

The three palaces of the First-Rank Upper Primordial Heavenly Officials—Left, Right, and Central—each govern twelve departments, totaling thirty-six departments. They universally administer the natural titles within the Supreme Void of Primordial Yang, collectively overseeing the registers of merits and demerits, life and death, of the Upper Perfected who have attained the Dao in past kalpas, those yet to attain it in the present blessings, and all common men and women. The August Jade Emperor, the assemblies of Heavenly Great Sages, the myriad deities of the Ten Directions, the Boundless Supreme Unity, the Upper Perfected of the Southern Culmen, the Perfected of Wondrous Conduct, the celestial bodies of the sun, moon, and stars, the innumerable hosts of the Jade Armillary Sphere, and all revered deities convene thrice yearly—on the fifteenth day of the first, seventh, and tenth months—to review and verify the registers of life, death, merits, and demerits of those who have attained the Dao in past kalpas, those yet to attain it, and all common men and women.

On these days, the examining officials of the Three Bureaus—Yin-Yang, Water-Fire, and Wind Blade—and the thirty-six departments’ officials and subordinates meticulously calculate the weight of merits, demerits, sins, and transgressions, along with their time limits. Each matter is distinctly recorded in the Green and Black Registers and presented to the Purple Tenuity and Supreme Ultimate Palaces—Left, Right, and Central. Those whose merits are complete and who are destined for immortality are recorded in the Purple Tenuity Palace. Those who have accumulated good deeds, reverence, and faith, and who uphold the Great Dao, are recorded in the Supreme Ultimate Left Palace. Those who have amassed evil and are unfit for the Dao, whose sins warrant death, are recorded in the Supreme Ultimate Right Palace.

For the Purple Tenuity Palace, names are inscribed in the Golden Register of Jade Records, and the Earthly Bureau is notified to erase their mortal records, while the Water Bureau removes their names from the registers. They are protected across the Three Realms and may not be violated, as decreed in the Writ of the Lady of Azure. For the Supreme Ultimate Left Palace, names are inscribed in the Azure Primordial Register and the Jade Calendar of Longevity in the Southern Upper Realm. The Water and Earth Bureaus are notified to provide separate protection, ensuring no violation, as decreed in the Writ of the Lady of Azure. For the Supreme Ultimate Right Palace, names are recorded in the Black Register and transferred to the Everlasting Night’s Nine Dark Bureau. The Water and Earth Bureaus are notified to seize and record the sinful souls, delivering them to the Execution Department for servitude. If the merits, demerits, and qi of the examined are not yet balanced, the matter is referred to the Three Assemblies for further review and rectification.

The Second-Rank Middle Primordial Earthly Officials, formed from the Primordial Cavernous Mixed Spirit Qi and the essence of the Ultimate Yellow, establish the Middle Primordial Three Palaces. The first palace is named the Cavernous Void Pure Spirit Palace, governed by the Primordial Cavernous Mixed Spirit Qi. It oversees the Five Emperors, the Five Marchmounts, all Perfected, and the deities and immortals of the earth who have attained the Dao. This palace comprises fifty billion, five myriad, fifty-five hundred million, fifty-five myriad layers of Mixed Spirit Qi, and its divine immortals, deities, and officials number ninety-nine million, nine hundred ninety-nine myriad. These are the souls of the deceased who possessed merits and have been delivered to assume duties in the Earthly Bureau, each with a set term. Upon fulfilling their merits, they may ascend to the ranks of Heavenly Immortals or be reborn among humans, with vacancies promptly filled to maintain their duties.

The Cavernous Void Pure Spirit Palace is also named the Luminous Dawn Martial City Palace and comprises three bureaus: Left, Right, and Central. The Left Bureau is named the Enduring Transgression Luminous Dawn Bureau and governs life, examined by the Palace of Great Yang Fire.

The Right Bureau is named the Zhòu-Jué Yīn Heavenly Bureau and governs death, examined by the Palace of Great Yin Water. The Central Bureau is named the Seven Non-Tranquil Radiance Bureau and oversees the records of life, death, and transgressions, as well as the trials of the Wind Blade.

Each of the three bureaus commands fifty million officials, collectively administering the fourteen departments of life, death, transgressions, and blessings:

The Supreme Mystery Central Origin Numinous Capital Department.
The Supreme Mystery Central Origin Upholding Rectitude Department.
The Supreme Mystery Central Origin Numinous Might Department.
The Supreme Mystery Central Origin Yellow Spirit Department.
The Supreme Mystery Central Origin Cavernous Mystery Department.
The Supreme Mystery Central Origin Might and Reverence Department.

The Supreme Mystery Central Origin Nine Capitals Department.
The Supreme Mystery Central Origin Five Assemblies Department.
The Supreme Mystery Central Origin Pervasive Radiance Department.
The Supreme Mystery Central Origin Ceremonial Model Department.
The Supreme Mystery Central Origin Nine Examinations Department.

These fourteen departments were established by the Supreme Mystery Lady of Azure and belong to the Cavernous Void Pure Spirit Palace, overseeing the examinations of the Left Bureau’s Great Yang Fire Officials, the Right Bureau’s Great Yin Water Officials, and the Central Bureau’s Wind Blade trials.

Each of the fourteen departments is staffed with one hundred twenty examining officials, one thousand two hundred examining clerks, twelve thousand examining soldiers, and one hundred twenty thousand examining scholars. They maintain the registers of merits, transgressions, and offenses for the perfected immortals of the Five Marchmounts, those who have attained the Dao, those who study but have yet to attain it, and all men and women among the common people.

Major examinations occur every three years, intermediate examinations every nine years, and minor examinations every twenty-four years. Major blessings are conferred every three years, intermediate blessings every nine years, and minor blessings every twenty-four years. Transgressions and blessings are both enacted, merits and offenses equally recompensed. Their registers are sealed within the cavern chambers of the Five Marchmounts.

The second rank of the Central Origin’s Left Palace is named the Southern Cavern Yang Palace, also called the Ancestral Heaven Palace, and governs all the spirit officials of the nine lands, four directions, eight extremities, and the registers of life for those who study but have yet to attain the Dao, as well as all men and women among the common people. Its palace is enveloped in fifty billion, five myriad, fifty-five hundred million, fifty-five myriad layers of Mixed Yellow Qi, and its earthly officials number ninety-nine million, nine hundred ninety-nine myriad—all souls of the deceased who possessed merits and have been delivered to assume their duties.

The Southern Cavern Yang Palace comprises three bureaus: Left, Right, and Central. The Left Bureau is named the Forgiving Affairs Bureau and governs life, examined by the Great Yang Fire Officials. The Right Bureau is named the Ancestral Spirit Bureau and governs death, examined by the Great Yin Water Officials. The Central Bureau is named the Numinous Tie Spirit Bureau and oversees the records of life, death, and transgressions, as well as the trials of the Wind Blade.

These fourteen departments were established by the Supreme Mystery Lady of Azure and belong to the Southern Cavern Yang Palace, overseeing the examinations of the Left Bureau’s Great Yang Fire Officials, the Right Bureau’s Great Yin Water Officials, and the Central Bureau’s Wind Blade trials.

They maintain the registers of merits, transgressions, and offenses for the spirit officials of the nine lands, four directions, eight extremities, those who study but have yet to attain the Dao, and all men and women among the common people. Their registers are sealed within the Stone Casket of the Primordial Yang Terrace of the Southern Cinnabar Cavern.

The second rank of the Central Origin’s Right Palace is named the Northern Feng Palace, also called the Yin Heaven Palace, and governs all spirit officials of the earth, the registers of transgressions and deaths for those who have attained the Dao in past lives, those who study but have yet to attain it, and all men and women among the common people. Its palace is enveloped in fifty billion, five myriad, fifty-five hundred million, fifty-five myriad layers of Mixed Yellow Qi, and its earthly officials number ninety-nine million, nine hundred ninety-nine myriad—all souls of the deceased who possessed merits and have been delivered to assume their duties.

The Northern Feng Palace comprises three bureaus: Left, Right, and Central. The Left Bureau is named the Linked Winding Springs Bureau and governs life, examined by the Great Yang Fire Officials. The Right Bureau is named the Supreme Execution Nine Darks Bureau and governs death, examined by the Great Yin Water Officials. The Central Bureau is named the Transgression Qi Salty Pond Bureau and oversees the records of life, death, and transgressions, as well as the trials of the Wind Blade.

Each of the three bureaus commands fifty million officials, collectively administering the fourteen departments of life, death, transgressions, and blessings:

These fourteen departments were established by the Supreme Mystery Lady of Azure and belong to the Northern Feng Palace, overseeing the examinations of the Left Bureau’s Great Yang Fire Officials, the Right Bureau’s Great Yin Water Officials, and the Central Bureau’s Wind Blade trials.

Each of the fourteen departments is staffed with one hundred twenty examining officials, one hundred twenty examining clerks, twelve thousand examining soldiers, and one hundred twenty thousand examining scholars. They maintain the black registers of transgressions and deaths for the nine lands, four directions, eight extremities, scholars who have yet to attain the Dao, and all men and women among the common people, as well as the records of blessings and retributions for those eligible for liberation.

The examination and summons cycles follow the same regulations as those of the Clear Numen Palace. Their ledgers and records are sealed within the Vault of Mysterious Yin at the Northern Wall. The Middle Primordial’s Second-Rank Earth Officials oversee the three palaces of the Left, Right, and Central Bureaus, each governing fourteen departments, totaling forty-two departments. These operate within the cavernous voids of mountains and grottos, all bearing natural designations, and universally govern the immortals, perfected beings, and numinous spirits of the Five Marchmounts, Four Directions, and Eight Extremities on earth, as well as those who have already attained the Dao in past ages, those presently in fortune who have yet to attain it, and all common men and women. They manage the ledgers of life and death, merits and transgressions, blessings and retributions, and the records of those who have perished or transcended.

All the Great Saints of the heavens, the myriad exalted deities of the ten directions, the perfected of wondrous conduct, the Southern and Northern Dippers, the celestial bodies of sun, moon, and stars, the Jade Armillary and Jade Balance, and the countless hosts of all revered deities customarily descend on the eight seasonal nodes to the Clear Numen Grotto-Yang and the Northern Feng’s three palaces to assemble and review the ledgers of life and death, merits and transgressions, blessings and retributions for all upon the earth. On such days, the Five Emperors of the earth, the immortals and perfected of the Five Marchmounts, the Earthly Bureau’s Four Offices and Earthly Emperors, the numinous officials of the Eight Extremities, the officials of the Three Realms, and all spirits invariably arrive in solemn array.

The three palaces and nine bureaus, along with the forty-two departments’ examination and summons officials, each oversee the Green and Black Ledgers of life and death. According to merits and transgressions, blessings and retributions, life and death, and transcendence, they calculate the weight of years and months. Every matter is distinguished in the Green and Black Ledgers and reported to the Three Palaces. On the fifteenth day of the first, seventh, and tenth months, the Three Palaces submit their reports to heaven. Once the ledgers of merits, transgressions, life, and death are finalized, those destined for life are reported to the Left Palace, those destined for immortality to the Central Palace, and those destined for death to the Right Palace. Upper and lower correspond precisely, with no discrepancy in the years, months, days, or even the finest details of merits, transgressions, life, and death. If any examination of *qi* remains unresolved, it is referred to the Three Assemblies for further review and correction before resubmission.

The Lower Primordial’s Third-Rank Water Officials, embodying the *qi* of cavernous primordial wind and marsh and the essence of vast dawn, establish the Lower Primordial’s Three Palaces. The first palace is named the Palace of the Dawn Valley Grotto-Source, also called the Azure Florescence Square-Cinnabar Palace. It governs the *qi* of cavernous primordial wind and marsh and is presided over by the Water Emperor, the Divine King of Dawn Valley, the River Earls of the Nine Waters, the water bureaus, the immortals and perfected, and all great deities of the waters. It maintains the ledgers of those who have already attained the Dao in past ages, those who have yet to attain it, and all common men and women. The palace is enveloped in fifty-five myriad, five thousand five hundred fifty-five myriad, five myriad layers of wind-and-marsh *qi*, and its immortals, water deities, and officials number ninety-nine myriad, nine thousand nine hundred ninety myriad. These are the souls of the deceased who possessed merit, having received deliverance to fill the ranks of water officials. Each serves for a set term, and upon fulfilling their merit, they may ascend to the ranks of celestial immortals or be reborn among humanity. Through such cycles, all may attain the status of higher immortals. Vacancies are filled as they arise to maintain their duties.

The Palace of Dawn Valley, also called the Azure Florescence Square-Cinnabar Palace, comprises the Left, Right, and Central Bureaus. The Left Bureau is named the Clear Primordial Numinous Abyss Bureau, overseeing life and the examinations of the Great Yang Fire Officials. The Right Bureau is named the Nine Waters Cold Night Bureau, overseeing death and the examinations of the Great Yin Water Officials. The Central Bureau is named the Northern Solstice Azure Numen Bureau, overseeing the trials of life, death, transgressions, and the Wind Blade. These fourteen departments were established by the Supreme Mystery Lady of Azure and belong to the Palace of Dawn Valley Grotto-Source, overseeing the examinations of the Left Bureau’s Great Yang Fire Officials, the Right Bureau’s Great Yin Water Officials, and the Central Bureau’s Wind Blade trials. Each of the fourteen departments is staffed with one hundred twenty examining officials, one thousand two hundred examining clerks, twelve thousand examining soldiers, and one hundred twenty thousand examining scholars. They maintain the records of merits and transgressions for the deities and spirits of the Nine Rivers, Three Rivers, and Four Seas, as well as all common men and women.

Major blessings are bestowed every three years, intermediate blessings every nine years, and minor blessings every twenty-four years. Transgressions and blessings are both enacted, merits and transgressions equally recompensed. Their ledgers are sealed within the grotto-chambers of the Nine Rivers.

The Lower Primordial’s Third-Rank Left Palace is named the Clear Cold Palace, also called the Southern Water Assembly Palace. It universally governs the myriad essences of the waters, the dragons and whales, the great assemblies of water disasters, the water mothers, the Dragon Gate’s cycles of deliverance, and the ledgers of all common men and women, managing the trials of life and death, merits and transgressions, and the weight of their severity. The palace is enveloped in fifty-five myriad, five thousand five hundred fifty-five myriad, five myriad layers of wind-and-marsh adamantine *qi*, and its immortals, water deities, and officials likewise number ninety-nine myriad, nine thousand nine hundred ninety myriad. These, too, are the souls of the deceased who possessed merit, having received deliverance to fill the ranks of water officials.

They govern the great and small karmic assemblies of the gods and spirits of the Nine Rivers, the Four Seas, the Three Rivers, the Huai, and the Ji water palaces; record the merits and transgressions of the people, men and women; and determine the retributions of transgressions and blessings, with time limits as set by the Yang Valley Palace. These records are sealed in the Yang Spring Grotto Chamber.

The Lower Primordial’s third-rank Right Palace is named the Northern Fengdu Palace, also called the Luo Feng Palace. It primarily governs the long-night dead ghosts, those sentenced to penal servitude for karmic terms, and the affairs of the myriad ghosts and spirits in the waters, as well as the black registers of those among the people, men and women, who are fated to die. This palace is composed of the qi of five hundred five million fifty-five thousand five hundred fifty-five layers of wind, marsh, purity, and ascetic practice. Among its divine immortals, water gods, and officials, there are ninety-nine million nine hundred ninety-nine thousand nine hundred ninety-nine, all of whom are souls of the deceased who have earned merit and, having received deliverance, are appointed to these official positions.

The Dao Lord bows his head and respectfully asks the Heavenly Worthy: What determines the weight of merits, the stages of deliverance, and the order of precedence? Past-life heavy debts are repaid by oneself and may extend to one’s descendants. The evil one commits in this life brings retribution upon oneself and may also mislead the deceased. Now, as we see among the common people—men and women—those who suffer in this life, enduring all manner of hardships and a hundred afflictions, unable to free themselves.

Moreover, we witness the tormented forms and souls of the deceased, dragged and tossed amidst the Three Wretched Paths and Five Sufferings, forever bound to the Long River’s icy courts, where wind and blade torment them across ten thousand kalpas without release. Scriptures and transmissions speak variously: some say the evil of past lives brings calamity upon descendants; others, that one’s own grave sins mislead the departed ancestors; still others, that good and evil each have their karmic counterparts, and that the roots of life and death, sin and blessing, lie in one’s own fate. If such karmic retribution—good or ill—belongs to each individual alone, why then do we speak of delayed or extended consequences? Yet it is also said that without the merit of deliverance, the condemned souls of past lives have no means of liberation. Once merit is established, the gates of life and death open wide. But if each bears their own karmic ties, and those who commit evil perish only to sink into eternal darkness for ten thousand kalpas, how could they ever amass such great merit to redeem themselves? If descendants build merit on behalf of the deceased, this would differ little in principle from the notion of delayed consequences. My understanding is shallow and narrow; I cannot fathom this. Since the Heavenly Worthy has inaugurated the teaching of great forgiveness, illuminating both life and death, it is fitting that the hidden and the manifest be made entirely clear, lest the ignorant remain confused by these two doctrines.

Having been elevated to this office and entrusted with its oversight, I must proclaim the true Dharma and enlighten future generations. May the sound of this teaching flow through all heavens, enduring for billions of kalpas, preserving the Orthodox Unity, so that all beings—living and dead—may receive its blessings, and the light of great forgiveness be made manifest. For this reason, I humbly present this inquiry, beseeching the Heavenly Worthy to grant a measure of compassion.

Thereupon, the Heavenly Worthy replied with joy: Excellent, excellent. Your question is of profound importance. Though you have penetrated the cavernous depths of the numinous, the hidden sources remain not fully exhausted; though you have surveyed the vast expanse, the Dragon Han remains obscure. Qi cannot be exhausted, numbers cannot be fathomed; death gives way to rebirth, darkness to light. The turning of heaven and earth is like a wheel’s revolution; the arising and ceasing of human life is like a shadow following form—thus, it is difficult to bring to an end. Qi flows in ceaseless succession, giving rise to manifold conditions of birth. Good and evil, fortune and misfortune—each has its root in fate. It is neither heaven nor earth, nor even other people, but precisely the mind. The mind is spirit. The body is not truly ours. That by which we live comes from the void and the natural, dwelling temporarily in the womb, transformed and born. The parents who conceived us are not our original parents; our true parents are not here. The love and reverence we owe our parents are supreme and without equal. Yet the parents who bore us in this life are but the karmic conditions of our temporary lodging, the source of nurture and upbringing to whom we repay gratitude with propriety, calling them father and mother.

Thus, the body we receive is not truly our own. It is but a dwelling, a temporary abode, a shelter for the self. We cling to it as form, manifesting existence and nonexistence. Therefore, those who attain the Dao no longer possess a body. When I have no body, what suffering can I know? Suffering arises only because I have a body. With a body, a hundred afflictions arise; without a body, one enters the natural, aligns with the Dao, and body and spirit become one. When body and spirit unite, it is the true body, returning to the original parents and attaining the Dao—free from suffering, never to die. Even if one enters nirvana, the spirit departs while the form does not perish to ash. In the end, it returns to its origin, never parted. If the body commits a hundred evils and dies after exhausting its sins, this is called death. Death is dissolution, a return to the parents of the borrowed womb. If the karmic conditions are not yet fulfilled, it cannot return to the true parents. The spirit, bound to toil and drudgery, the form reduced to dust, the dust scattered and transformed into *shuang*. When the soul is liberated, it merges with the *shuang*, and thus soul and *shuang* transform as one, gaining rebirth and becoming human again. Body and spirit follow one another, never parting.

In this way, good and evil each have their counterparts, belonging to the individual alone. How can blame be laid upon ancestors or descendants? Before the Dragon Han, extending to the Red Clarity, the old texts state that life and death arise from the self, neither extending upward nor flowing downward; sin and blessing are borne by the individual alone. After the Red Clarity, reaching the High Antiquity, the human heart was corrupted: men and women lost their purity, jealousy and harm arose, and they turned to mutual destruction. The heart could not stand firm, drawing in ancestors above and descendants below as witnesses, swearing oaths before the gods. Yet they lacked self-trust, violating their vows, leading the Three Officials to record their transgressions. Upon death, they became ghosts, misleading the departed above and burdening descendants below, entangling all in calamity, great and small, without end, bringing ruin to the entire clan. Such evil-doers bring great misfortune upon themselves. The clear teachings of the Dharma state that they shall never be equaled. Those of insight accumulate merit, seeking it within themselves, not from others. Are the ancient texts of the Perfected not to be trusted?

The Heavenly Worthy further addressed the Most High Dao Lord: The Dao of great compassion places the deliverance of others first. Without merit, there is no reward; without virtue, no promotion; without faith, no deliverance; without practice, no immortality. Those who establish merit do so for the sake of heaven and earth, the Three Luminaries, the sovereign, the myriad people, their ancestors, their family, all beings, and themselves. The scriptures say: If you wish to deliver yourself, first deliver others. If all others are not delivered, you yourself will never be delivered. Great compassion is vast and boundless, extending mercy without end, revered by heaven and humanity—how much more so for the seven generations of ancestors? Sin and blessing may not be transferred, but when it comes to merit, there is the bond of karmic gratitude. Sincere remorse moves heaven to reverse one’s fate; the power of single-minded devotion opens the way for both humans and spirits. How much more so for those who, born of borrowed qi and nurtured in the womb, owe their existence and upbringing to others? When love and affection run deep, how can one not strive to build great merit, to deliver and repay the destitute souls?

Since the Dragon Han era through to the Red Clarity, those who attained the Dao and abide in present blessings—whose households are pure and noble, whose good affinities extend into future lives—have all accumulated merit and piled up virtue, their achievements moving the various heavens to bestow reciprocal rewards. As for those bound in the long night of the Nine Dark Realms, whose karmic debts have been resolved, none have escaped through anything but the power of merit: ransoming, delivering, and returning them to the human realm. In the Southern Ridge’s Vermilion Palace and the Nine Capitals’ upper registers, all their names are recorded—such is the principle of karmic retribution, precise to the finest detail. The reckoning of years and months is utterly clear.

The Dao Lord bowed in reverence: Having now heard the Heavenly Worthy expound the karmic correspondences of merit and retribution, all doubts have instantly dissolved; my heart rejoices and my mind is at ease, with no lingering obstructions. I shall diligently apply my heart to propagating the Great Dharma, universally revealing it to all the people—men, women, and children—throughout the boundless worlds of the various heavens, that all may comply and fully perceive its truth.

The Most High Dao Lord addressed the Heavenly Worthy: Since you have deigned to awaken and resolve all doubts, I now inquire which among the merits should be prioritized. Are the revealed true statutes, the supreme wisdom of the highest grade for ransoming the roots of sin, sufficient in themselves, or are there additional methods? Does the solemn vow to ransom sins, the instruction of the young and ignorant, the establishment of quiet abodes, the offering of reverence to masters and treasures, the distribution of incense and oil, the lighting of lamps to illuminate the night, the cultivation of good thoughts, the deliverance of sentient beings, the practice of compassion, loyalty, and filial piety, the relief of the destitute, and the feeding of the hundred birds—all without stint—carry varying degrees of merit? Are they of the same rank, or do they differ in nobility and humility? I humbly request your instruction.

The Heavenly Worthy replied: In the establishment of merit, there is no great nor small, no high nor low—its power is equal. The weight of karmic retribution depends on the heart of the practitioner. If one’s heart remains unwavering in diligence, enduring hardship without retreat, such merit is beyond measure, and its virtue beyond naming. Yet if one merely possesses sincere intention but does not persist in practice, one may only escape sin without attaining further reward. Those who act without true heart, offering empty gestures, gain nothing from their efforts.

The wealthy, cherishing their treasures, refuse to distribute or ransom the roots of sin; they merely contemplate the Dao in their hearts, hoping for great reward—such efforts are futile and profitless. How could the heavenly Dao demand one’s wealth, compelling merit-making? It observes the stinginess of the heart and examines the sincerity of intent: if one possesses but does not give, what can one seek? Yet the poor who arouse the heart, whose will is firm and bright, who toil without complaint in the master’s gate—such individuals are seen by the Dao, and their merit moves the various heavens. Thus, offering wealth corresponds to the heart, and offering the heart corresponds to wealth—their merit is equal.

The ancients sought the heart; the degenerate age seeks wealth. The ancients attained immortality through nothing but the heart; the degenerate age attains deliverance through nothing but wealth. Why is this so? In the degenerate age, wealth is prized over the Dao. If a thousand pounds of gold and a scroll of immortal scripture were placed in a barren mountain, the people of this age would covet the gold, not the scripture. Gold can only bring bodily affliction; the scripture can extend one’s life. One ought to know this, yet one cannot escape stinginess and greed. If one cannot free oneself from greed and stinginess, how can one fully realize the Dao? Thus, it is not that the Dao fails to flourish among people—this is what is meant.

The statutes of luminous truth and the supreme wisdom of the highest grade for ransoming the roots of sin, applied to the realm of birth and death, are of the utmost gravity. As for scholars who have not yet entered samadhi, dwelling amid the clamor of the world, how can they avoid gains and losses? In every action and deed, sin and blessing proceed together. Thus, the Three Bureaus, Nine Courts, One Hundred Twenty Offices, and the left and right officials of yin and yang, water and fire, who oversee human gains and losses—those who accumulate good merit have their names recorded in the left registers, while those who commit evil have theirs in the right. Each is assessed according to the years, months, days, and the nearness or distance of their merit, with the weight of days determining the gravity. Karmic retribution converges like the meeting of tidal waters, its appointed time inevitable, with not a single error. The difference lies only in the weight and proximity of the reckoning.

I now declare this to you so that you may diligently proclaim it, that all good men and women of future generations may universally know that heaven and earth possess an unerring resonance, and that these words are truly real. I now transmit the method of atonement for the Three Primes. The ancient texts of the Primordial Dao of the Origin were concealed in the Three Prime Palaces, revealed but once in ten thousand kalpas, never passed down to the lower worlds. Those who behold their titles may uproot their karmic roots and untie their bonds of their own accord. Treasure and practice them, and great fortune will surely follow. Treat them lightly or leak their secrets, and calamity will strike, annihilating one’s clan. With utter sincerity, deeply guard these statutes.

The Dao Lord rejoiced, bowed his head, and paid homage. At that moment, all the heavens simultaneously proclaimed their approval, bowed their heads, and received the teaching. Thus concludes *The Scripture on the Weight of Merit in the Three Prime Precepts of the Upper Cavern of Mystery and Numinous Treasure*.

*The Scripture on the Merits and Gravity of the Three Primal Precepts from the Supreme Cavernous Mystery Numinous Treasure*

Thus spake the Heavenly Worthy:

In the Upper Primal Realm, the Celestial Officials of the First Order, where primordial qi first congeals and the Three Luminaries dawn in radiance, the essences of azure, yellow, and white qi coalesce to establish the Three Palaces of the Upper Primal. The first of these is named the Supreme Cavernous Mystery Primordial Yang Seven-Jewel Purple Tenuity Palace. Therein resides the azure primordial yang qi, governing the Perfected of the Upper Realms, the Celestial August Emperor of the Jade Void, the Divine Sovereigns of the Heavens, and the exalted deities of the highest sanctity.

This palace is arrayed in fifty-five myriad, five thousand five hundred fifty-five myriad, five myriad layers, enveloped likewise in fifty-five myriad, five thousand five hundred fifty-five myriad, five myriad layers of azure yang qi. Within it, the divine immortals and their retinues number fifty-five myriad, five thousand five hundred fifty-five myriad, five myriad, as do their multitudes—all formed from the spontaneous coagulation of azure primordial qi into human form. Their raiment is of azure feathered flight-garments.

Within the Purple Tenuity Palace lies the Talisman of Prolonged Life. When this talisman is inscribed and placed in the eight directions, the qi of those regions rushes forth in response, manifesting as human beings. Should the talisman be destroyed and burned in fire, the people dissolve with the smoke, reverting to qi. None but those who have attained the Dao with golden tablets and jade names may wield it. Its script emerges but once every forty thousand kalpas, overseen by the Fire Officials of the Great Yang and enacted by the Upper Repository of the Supreme Cavernous Mystery.

The Purple Tenuity Palace contains three bureaus: left, right, and central. The Left Bureau governs life, examined by the Fire Officials of the Great Yang. The Right Bureau governs death, examined by the Water Officials of the Great Yin. The Central Bureau governs the records of life, death, transgressions, and the trials of the Wind Blade.

Each bureau commands a retinue of ninety million officials, collectively administering the twelve departments of life, death, transgressions, and blessings:

1. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Illuminated Perfection Department
2. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Surveillance and Rectification Department
3. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Brahman Conduct Department
4. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Unfolding Numinosity Department
5. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Spirit-Restraining Department
6. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Luminous Clarity Department
7. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Rectified Spirits Department
8. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Unfolding Clarity Department
9. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Three Capitals Department
10. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Southern Ascendant Department
11. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Primordial Merit Department
12. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Three Numinosities Department

These twelve departments were established by the Supreme Cavernous Mystery Lady of Azure, subordinate to the Purple Tenuity Palace. They govern the Left Bureau’s Great Yang Fire Officials, the Right Bureau’s Great Yin Water Officials, and the Central Bureau’s trials by Wind Blade. Each department comprises one hundred twenty examining officials, one thousand two hundred examining scribes, twelve thousand examining soldiers, and one hundred twenty thousand examining scholars. They oversee the registers of the Upper Perfected who have attained the Dao in past kalpas, those yet to attain it in the present blessings, and the merits and transgressions of all men and women among the common folk.

Major trials occur every three years, intermediate trials every nine years, and minor trials every twenty-four years. Major blessings are bestowed every three years, intermediate blessings every nine years, and minor blessings every twenty-four years. Transgressions and blessings are meted out together, merits and demerits recompensed alike. The ledgers of good and evil are stored within the Seven-Jewel Casket of the Illuminated Perfection Jade Coffer in the Cavernous Mystery Capital.

In the Upper Primal Realm, the left palace of the primordial yellow qi of the Central Yellow is named the Supreme Cavernous Mystery Primordial Yellow Supreme Ultimate Left Palace. Therein resides the primordial yellow qi of the Origin, governing the registers of life for the Upper Perfected who have attained the Dao in past kalpas, those yet to attain it, and all men and women among the common folk.

This palace is arrayed in fifty-five myriad, five thousand five hundred fifty-five myriad, five myriad layers, enveloped likewise in fifty-five myriad, five thousand five hundred fifty-five myriad, five myriad layers of primordial yellow qi. Within it, the divine immortals and their retinues number fifty-five myriad, five thousand five hundred fifty-five myriad, five myriad, as do their multitudes—all formed from the spontaneous coagulation of primordial yellow qi into human form. Their raiment is of yellow feathered flight-garments.

Within the Supreme Ultimate Left Palace lies the Talisman of Summoning Spirits. Its method of use follows the same rites and standards as the Talisman of Prolonged Life in the Purple Tenuity Palace. It is overseen by the Wind Blade Examining Officials and enacted by the Left Repository of the Supreme Cavernous Mystery.

The Supreme Ultimate Left Palace contains three bureaus: left, right, and central. The Left Bureau governs life, examined by the Great Yang Fire Officials. The Right Bureau governs death, examined by the Great Yin Water Officials. The Central Bureau governs the records of life, death, transgressions, and the trials of the Wind Blade.

Each bureau commands a retinue of ninety million officials, collectively administering the twelve departments of life, death, transgressions, and blessings:

1. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Illuminated Brahman Department
2. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Majestic Numinosity Department
3. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Grand Constancy Department
4. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Grand Purity Department
5. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Proclaiming Majesty Department
6. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Illuminated Capital Department
7. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Capital Numinosity Department
8. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Grand Ceremony Department
9. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Illuminated Dharma Department
10. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Examining Rectification Department
11. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Illuminated Majesty Department
12. The Supreme Cavernous Mystery Upper Primal Nine Capitals Department

These twelve departments were established by the Supreme Cavernous Mystery Lady of Azure, subordinate to the Primordial Yellow Supreme Ultimate Left Palace. They govern the Left Bureau’s Great Yang Fire Palace, the Right Bureau’s Great Yin Water Palace, and the Central Bureau’s trials by Wind Blade. Each department comprises one hundred twenty examining officials, one thousand two hundred examining scribes, twelve thousand examining soldiers, and one hundred twenty thousand examining scholars. They oversee the life registers of the Upper Perfected who have attained the Dao in past kalpas, those yet to attain it in the present blessings, and all men and women among the common folk, as well as those destined to attain immortality with jade tablets on the right.

On that day, the Boundless Heavenly Worthy, the Ten Directions’ Great Sage Assembly, the Thirty-Two Heavenly Emperors, the Flying Heavenly Divine Kings, the Supreme Jade Void Perfected Great Spirits, the Boundless Great Dao’s Most High Lord Lao, the Venerable Masters, the Five Elder Emperors, the Southern and Northern Poles and Eastern and Western Flowers, the Nine Numinous Perfected Mothers, the Southern Upper Primordial Lady, and the Jade Maiden of Supreme Harmony all arrive together at the Three Primordials’ Palace. Once the assembly of sages is gathered, the flying immortals, divine immortals, Perfected Ones, Jade Maidens, the Longevity Directors of Life and Death, the Southern and Northern Dippers, the celestial sun, moon, and stars, the Jade Armillary Sphere, and all divine beings arrive in solemn array.

The Three Primordials’ left, right, and central palaces’ Three Officials and nine mansions’ one hundred twenty bureaus, the yin and yang, left and right, water and fire, wind and blade examination officials, each calculate the ledgers of life and death in heaven and on earth, cross-examining one another. Those with good deeds are recorded in the Azure Register; those with heavy transgressions are inscribed in the Black Register. Each is reported to the Three Officials with their merits and transgressions, good and evil, without the slightest error.

On that day, those who follow the Three Primordials’ method of repentance, purify themselves with fasting, burn incense, and act in accordance with the Mysterious Regulations for one hundred days will have their earthly dwellings specially guarded, their gates and defenses secured. After eight years of practice, they will all receive the Three Officials’ protection and recommendation, their names inscribed in the Azure Register, and they will attain the rank of Upper Immortal, never losing their destined place in the Dao.

The Dao Lord bows his head and respectfully asks the Heavenly Worthy: What determines the weight of merits, the stages of deliverance, and the order of precedence? Past-life heavy debts are repaid by oneself and may extend to one’s descendants. The evil one commits in this life brings retribution upon oneself and may also mislead the deceased. Now, as we see among the common people—men and women—those who suffer in this life, enduring all manner of hardships and a hundred afflictions, unable to free themselves.

chunks.original_text: 又见死者形魂忧恼，流曳三途五苦之中，长河寒庭，风刀万劫不得解脱。 经传或云先身行恶，殃流子孙。 或云己身罪重，上误先亡。 或云善恶各有缘对，生死罪福各有命根。 如此报应善恶缘对，则各归一身，不应复有延误之言。 又云自非功德拔度，先世谪魂则无由解脱。 功德既建，则生死开泰。 若各有缘对，行恶之者，死则长沦万劫，长挚幽夜，何缘复得建此大功，以自拔赎。 若子孙建功，上为亡者，则与延误，理无复异。 愚情浅狭，所未能了。 天尊既开大宥之化，生死皆明，宜#1使幽显尽然有判，不令愚暗惑於二论。 既蒙饰擢，位任总司，当宣正法，开示来生。 欲使法音流演诸天，亿劫不绝，正一长存，生死蒙福，大宥明焉。 缘兹上白，伏愿天尊特垂一及怜。 於是天尊欢喜答曰：善哉，善哉。 子之所问，要乎深矣。 子虽洞灵墟，而幽源未尽，虽览大有，而龙汉难明。 气不可极，数难可穷，死而复生，幽而复明。 天地运转，如车之轮，人之生灭，如影随形，故难终也。 气气相续，种种生缘，善恶祸福，各有命根。 非天非地，亦又非人，正由心也。 心则神也。 形非我有也。 我所以得生者，从虚无自然中来，因缘寄胎，受化而生也。 我受胎父母，亦非我始生父母也，我真父母不在此也。 父母爱重，尊高无上。 今所生父母，是我寄附因缘，禀受育养之恩，故以礼报，而称为父母焉。 故我受形，亦非我形也。 寄之为屋宅，因之为营室，以舍我也。 附之以为形，示之以有无。 故得道者，无复有形也。 及我无身，我有何患。 所以有患者，为我有身耳。 有身则百患生，无身则入自然，立行合道，则身神一也。 身神并一，则为真身，归於始生父母，而成道也，无复患也，终不死也。 纵使灭度，则神往而形不灰也。 终身归其本，不相去也。 身犯百恶，罪竟而死，名曰死也。 死则灭坏，归於寄胎父母。 罪缘未尽，不得归於真父母也。 神充涂役，形成灰尘，灰尘飞化而成爽也。 魂神解脱，则与爽混合，故魂爽变化，合成一也，而得更生，还为人也。 形神相随，终不相去也。 如此善恶，身各有对，岂可咎於先亡及后子孙乎。 龙汉之前，逮至赤明，旧文生死各由一身，亦不上延，亦不下流，罪福止一，各以身当。 赤明以后，逮及上皇，人心破坏，男女不纯，嫉害争竞，更相残伤，心不自固，上引祖父，下引子孙，以为证誓，质告神明，竟不自信，负违誓言，致三官结簿，身没鬼官，上误先亡，下流子孙，致有殃逮，大小相牵，终天无解，祸及一宗。 此罪恶之人，自求大殃。 至法明言，永不得同。 达士积行，当取诸身，无求乎人。 明真旧典，岂虚言哉。 天尊重告太上道君曰：大慈之道，度人为先，非功不赏，非德不迁，非信不度，非行不仙也。 夫建功德者，一为天地，一为三光，一为帝主，一为兆民，一为祖世，一为家门，一为众生，一为己身。 经云：夫欲度身，当先度人。 众人不得度，终不度我身。 大慈广远，惠逮无穷，天人所仰，况在七祖父母乎。 罪福可不相加，至於功德，故有因缘之恩，精诚自责，天为回度，一志之感，人神同开，况於寄胎禀气，而生受其育养生成者哉。 慈爱既浓，岂可不为重建功德，以相开度，施报穷魂乎。

Moreover, we witness the tormented forms and souls of the deceased, dragged and tossed amidst the Three Wretched Paths and Five Sufferings, forever bound to the Long River’s icy courts, where wind and blade torment them across ten thousand kalpas without release. Scriptures and transmissions speak variously: some say the evil of past lives brings calamity upon descendants; others, that one’s own grave sins mislead the departed ancestors; still others, that good and evil each have their karmic counterparts, and that the roots of life and death, sin and blessing, lie in one’s own fate. If such karmic retribution—good or ill—belongs to each individual alone, why then do we speak of delayed or extended consequences? Yet it is also said that without the merit of deliverance, the condemned souls of past lives have no means of liberation. Once merit is established, the gates of life and death open wide. But if each bears their own karmic ties, and those who commit evil perish only to sink into eternal darkness for ten thousand kalpas, how could they ever amass such great merit to redeem themselves? If descendants build merit on behalf of the deceased, this would differ little in principle from the notion of delayed consequences. My understanding is shallow and narrow; I cannot fathom this. Since the Heavenly Worthy has inaugurated the teaching of great forgiveness, illuminating both life and death, it is fitting that the hidden and the manifest be made entirely clear, lest the ignorant remain confused by these two doctrines.

Having been elevated to this office and entrusted with its oversight, I must proclaim the true Dharma and enlighten future generations. May the sound of this teaching flow through all heavens, enduring for billions of kalpas, preserving the Orthodox Unity, so that all beings—living and dead—may receive its blessings, and the light of great forgiveness be made manifest. For this reason, I humbly present this inquiry, beseeching the Heavenly Worthy to grant a measure of compassion.

Thereupon, the Heavenly Worthy replied with joy: Excellent, excellent. Your question is of profound importance. Though you have penetrated the cavernous depths of the numinous, the hidden sources remain not fully exhausted; though you have surveyed the vast expanse, the Dragon Han remains obscure. Qi cannot be exhausted, numbers cannot be fathomed; death gives way to rebirth, darkness to light. The turning of heaven and earth is like a wheel’s revolution; the arising and ceasing of human life is like a shadow following form—thus, it is difficult to bring to an end. Qi flows in ceaseless succession, giving rise to manifold conditions of birth. Good and evil, fortune and misfortune—each has its root in fate. It is neither heaven nor earth, nor even other people, but precisely the mind. The mind is spirit. The body is not truly ours. That by which we live comes from the void and the natural, dwelling temporarily in the womb, transformed and born. The parents who conceived us are not our original parents; our true parents are not here. The love and reverence we owe our parents are supreme and without equal. Yet the parents who bore us in this life are but the karmic conditions of our temporary lodging, the source of nurture and upbringing to whom we repay gratitude with propriety, calling them father and mother.

Thus, the body we receive is not truly our own. It is but a dwelling, a temporary abode, a shelter for the self. We cling to it as form, manifesting existence and nonexistence. Therefore, those who attain the Dao no longer possess a body. When I have no body, what suffering can I know? Suffering arises only because I have a body. With a body, a hundred afflictions arise; without a body, one enters the natural, aligns with the Dao, and body and spirit become one. When body and spirit unite, it is the true body, returning to the original parents and attaining the Dao—free from suffering, never to die. Even if one enters nirvana, the spirit departs while the form does not perish to ash. In the end, it returns to its origin, never parted. If the body commits a hundred evils and dies after exhausting its sins, this is called death. Death is dissolution, a return to the parents of the borrowed womb. If the karmic conditions are not yet fulfilled, it cannot return to the true parents. The spirit, bound to toil and drudgery, the form reduced to dust, the dust scattered and transformed into *shuang*. When the soul is liberated, it merges with the *shuang*, and thus soul and *shuang* transform as one, gaining rebirth and becoming human again. Body and spirit follow one another, never parting.

In this way, good and evil each have their counterparts, belonging to the individual alone. How can blame be laid upon ancestors or descendants? Before the Dragon Han, extending to the Red Clarity, the old texts state that life and death arise from the self, neither extending upward nor flowing downward; sin and blessing are borne by the individual alone. After the Red Clarity, reaching the High Antiquity, the human heart was corrupted: men and women lost their purity, jealousy and harm arose, and they turned to mutual destruction. The heart could not stand firm, drawing in ancestors above and descendants below as witnesses, swearing oaths before the gods. Yet they lacked self-trust, violating their vows, leading the Three Officials to record their transgressions. Upon death, they became ghosts, misleading the departed above and burdening descendants below, entangling all in calamity, great and small, without end, bringing ruin to the entire clan. Such evil-doers bring great misfortune upon themselves. The clear teachings of the Dharma state that they shall never be equaled. Those of insight accumulate merit, seeking it within themselves, not from others. Are the ancient texts of the Perfected not to be trusted?

The Heavenly Worthy further addressed the Most High Dao Lord: The Dao of great compassion places the deliverance of others first. Without merit, there is no reward; without virtue, no promotion; without faith, no deliverance; without practice, no immortality. Those who establish merit do so for the sake of heaven and earth, the Three Luminaries, the sovereign, the myriad people, their ancestors, their family, all beings, and themselves. The scriptures say: If you wish to deliver yourself, first deliver others. If all others are not delivered, you yourself will never be delivered. Great compassion is vast and boundless, extending mercy without end, revered by heaven and humanity—how much more so for the seven generations of ancestors? Sin and blessing may not be transferred, but when it comes to merit, there is the bond of karmic gratitude. Sincere remorse moves heaven to reverse one’s fate; the power of single-minded devotion opens the way for both humans and spirits. How much more so for those who, born of borrowed qi and nurtured in the womb, owe their existence and upbringing to others? When love and affection run deep, how can one not strive to build great merit, to deliver and repay the destitute souls?

chunks.original_text: 自龙汉以来，至于赤明，得道者及见在福中，门户清贵，善缘来生，莫非积功累德，勋感诸天，以致交报。 及九幽长夜宿责之身得解脱者，莫非功德拔赎开度，以还人中也。 南陵朱宫九都上格，悉有其名，报应之理，毫分无失也。 年月相推，甚有分明。 道君作礼：今闻天尊告诸缘对功德报应，诸疑顿尽，心欢意释，无复余滞。 辄当勤心，奉宣大法，普示诸天无极世界百姓子男女人，咸令遵承，一切见明矣。 太上道君上白天尊：既垂开悟，诸疑并了，不审功德，何者为先。 见明真科文及智慧上品拔赎罪根，为尽如是，为复有余方，信誓拔赎，及教化童蒙，建立静舍，供养师宝，布诸香油，燃灯照夜，心行善念，救度众生，慈爱忠孝，布散穷乏，饷饴百乌，无有吝惜。 其中功德，为有轻重，为同一等高下尊卑。 愿垂告示。 天尊告曰：凡建功德，无大无小，无高无下，其功等耳。 轻重报应，由人心也。 心行不怠，苦而不退，此功难称，德亦难名。 徒有至心，行之不专，正可得免罪而已。 无心而浮好，徒施而无获也。 富室之家，爱惜财宝，不肯施散，拔赎罪根，徒推心求道，希望大报，此将徒劳而无益也。 天道何其责人财宝，强使作功德，故观其悭心，质求其意，有而不散，将何求哉。 穷而发心，意志坚明，勤苦师门，劳不为惮，道已鉴之，如此之辈，则功感诸天。 故施财以对心，推心以对财，其功等尔。 古人求心，末世求财，古人非心不仙，末世非财不度。 所以尔者，末世贵财而不贵道也。 以黄金万斤，仙经一部，施於穷山，末世乃当贪取此金，岂贪仙经也。 黄金克为身患，仙经克得命长。 亦合知如此，祇自不能免於悭贪，既自不能免於贪悭，安得为究道耶。 故非道弘人，此之谓也。 明真科法，智慧上品，拔度罪根，施於生死，其法甚重。 至於学士，身未入定，处於嚣尘，能无得失？ 举动施为，罪福并行，故三官九府百二十曹、左右阴阳水火考官，司人得失，善功者列言左官，行恶者列言右宫，各随年月日数远近，以考促之功德，日数轻重。 报应如涛水之会，必至之期，万无一失也。 但以轻重远近言之耳。 今故相告，勤为宣示，咸令来生男女善人，普知天地有不期之响应，真实之言也。 今以三元谢罪之法相付。 元始上道旧文，秘於三元宫中，万劫一行，不传下世。 有盼其篇目，宿根自拔，结缚自释。 宝而行之，必招大福。 轻而泄之，祸至灭族。 言丹心尽，深慎科法。 道君欢喜，稽首作礼。 是时诸天同时称善，稽首奉行。 上洞玄灵宝三元品戒功德轻重经竟 #1 宜：原误作「宣」，据敦煌S.6659抄本改。
chunks.translated_text:
Since the Dragon Han era through to the Red Clarity, those who attained the Dao and abide in present blessings—whose households are pure and noble, whose good affinities extend into future lives—have all accumulated merit and piled up virtue, their achievements moving the various heavens to bestow reciprocal rewards. As for those bound in the long night of the Nine Dark Realms, whose karmic debts have been resolved, none have escaped through anything but the power of merit: ransoming, delivering, and returning them to the human realm. In the Southern Ridge’s Vermilion Palace and the Nine Capitals’ upper registers, all their names are recorded—such is the principle of karmic retribution, precise to the finest detail. The reckoning of years and months is utterly clear.

The Dao Lord bowed in reverence: Having now heard the Heavenly Worthy expound the karmic correspondences of merit and retribution, all doubts have instantly dissolved; my heart rejoices and my mind is at ease, with no lingering obstructions. I shall diligently apply my heart to propagating the Great Dharma, universally revealing it to all the people—men, women, and children—throughout the boundless worlds of the various heavens, that all may comply and fully perceive its truth.

The Most High Dao Lord addressed the Heavenly Worthy: Since you have deigned to awaken and resolve all doubts, I now inquire which among the merits should be prioritized. Are the revealed true statutes, the supreme wisdom of the highest grade for ransoming the roots of sin, sufficient in themselves, or are there additional methods? Does the solemn vow to ransom sins, the instruction of the young and ignorant, the establishment of quiet abodes, the offering of reverence to masters and treasures, the distribution of incense and oil, the lighting of lamps to illuminate the night, the cultivation of good thoughts, the deliverance of sentient beings, the practice of compassion, loyalty, and filial piety, the relief of the destitute, and the feeding of the hundred birds—all without stint—carry varying degrees of merit? Are they of the same rank, or do they differ in nobility and humility? I humbly request your instruction.

The Heavenly Worthy replied: In the establishment of merit, there is no great nor small, no high nor low—its power is equal. The weight of karmic retribution depends on the heart of the practitioner. If one’s heart remains unwavering in diligence, enduring hardship without retreat, such merit is beyond measure, and its virtue beyond naming. Yet if one merely possesses sincere intention but does not persist in practice, one may only escape sin without attaining further reward. Those who act without true heart, offering empty gestures, gain nothing from their efforts.

The wealthy, cherishing their treasures, refuse to distribute or ransom the roots of sin; they merely contemplate the Dao in their hearts, hoping for great reward—such efforts are futile and profitless. How could the heavenly Dao demand one’s wealth, compelling merit-making? It observes the stinginess of the heart and examines the sincerity of intent: if one possesses but does not give, what can one seek? Yet the poor who arouse the heart, whose will is firm and bright, who toil without complaint in the master’s gate—such individuals are seen by the Dao, and their merit moves the various heavens. Thus, offering wealth corresponds to the heart, and offering the heart corresponds to wealth—their merit is equal.

The ancients sought the heart; the degenerate age seeks wealth. The ancients attained immortality through nothing but the heart; the degenerate age attains deliverance through nothing but wealth. Why is this so? In the degenerate age, wealth is prized over the Dao. If a thousand pounds of gold and a scroll of immortal scripture were placed in a barren mountain, the people of this age would covet the gold, not the scripture. Gold can only bring bodily affliction; the scripture can extend one’s life. One ought to know this, yet one cannot escape stinginess and greed. If one cannot free oneself from greed and stinginess, how can one fully realize the Dao? Thus, it is not that the Dao fails to flourish among people—this is what is meant.

The statutes of luminous truth and the supreme wisdom of the highest grade for ransoming the roots of sin, applied to the realm of birth and death, are of the utmost gravity. As for scholars who have not yet entered samadhi, dwelling amid the clamor of the world, how can they avoid gains and losses? In every action and deed, sin and blessing proceed together. Thus, the Three Bureaus, Nine Courts, One Hundred Twenty Offices, and the left and right officials of yin and yang, water and fire, who oversee human gains and losses—those who accumulate good merit have their names recorded in the left registers, while those who commit evil have theirs in the right. Each is assessed according to the years, months, days, and the nearness or distance of their merit, with the weight of days determining the gravity. Karmic retribution converges like the meeting of tidal waters, its appointed time inevitable, with not a single error. The difference lies only in the weight and proximity of the reckoning.

I now declare this to you so that you may diligently proclaim it, that all good men and women of future generations may universally know that heaven and earth possess an unerring resonance, and that these words are truly real. I now transmit the method of atonement for the Three Primes. The ancient texts of the Primordial Dao of the Origin were concealed in the Three Prime Palaces, revealed but once in ten thousand kalpas, never passed down to the lower worlds. Those who behold their titles may uproot their karmic roots and untie their bonds of their own accord. Treasure and practice them, and great fortune will surely follow. Treat them lightly or leak their secrets, and calamity will strike, annihilating one’s clan. With utter sincerity, deeply guard these statutes.

The Dao Lord rejoiced, bowed his head, and paid homage. At that moment, all the heavens simultaneously proclaimed their approval, bowed their heads, and received the teaching. Thus concludes *The Scripture on the Weight of Merit in the Three Prime Precepts of the Upper Cavern of Mystery and Numinous Treasure*.
